data.text: The Dangers of Bicycle Touring in Africa!

**The Dangers of Cycling in Africa!** Everyone knows about the wild animals, even ebola and malaria, but don‚Äôt forget about RABIES! ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just another one of the things that can kill you. It won‚Äôt prevent rabies. It will just give you a little more time to get to a doctor,‚Äù I was told. In Zambia, I gave myself the 1st of 3 doses of a rabies vaccination‚Ä¶you know, to give me a little more time to get to a doctor should I get bit by a rabid dog while bikepacking. More adventure stories here ‚Äç‚¨áÔ∏è **IG: jerrykopack**

I worked in laboratories with rabies, and as far as I can tell, there is no indication that a full set of rabies vaccination won't prevent rabies. https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/vis/vis-statements/rabies.pdf
data.author: Stephen Cieply

data.text: really? Tell us more? Can you please describe the whole protocol as you understand how it should go.
data.author: Andrea Collisson

data.text: you seem to be saying that the rabies vaccines dont work. I doubt this is true.
data.author: Andrea Collisson

data.text: with the double negative I think he's implying the opposite, that the rabies vaccine definitely prevents rabies?
data.author: Scott Boag

data.text: Well that there's no evidence that it doesn't and there's plenty of evidencethat it does, which is a similar sentiment. Absolutes aren't too common in science.
data.author: Stephen Cieply

data.text: I see no case reports of a rabies breakthrough infection, one in which a person was fully vaccinated pre-exposure and the person later came down with rabies. While it's possible I guess, it's absent from the medical literature. Strange 1 off events like breakthrough infections to highly effective vaccines are typically published in the medical literature.
data.author: Stephen Cieply

data.text: from my understanding, from discussions with my doctor when I got it, it‚Äôs not considered a ‚Äúfull‚Äù vaccine as there‚Äôs isn‚Äôt enough data. Most likely, just not enough bite victims recorded in the system and since rabies is so deadly, experimental exposure is not done. I got the vaccine and would require a follow up shot just in case if bitten/scratched, etc. it might not be necessary, but better safe than sorry.
data.author: Suzen Dent

data.text: Ok, that's great info. I was told be different doctors both in the US and in Zambia, that the full course of 3 shots only buys you extra time
data.author: Jerry Kopack

data.text: that is the truth. You still have to go and get follow up shots if you get bitten. If youve had the pre bite vaccines and then get bitten you do not have to be so frantic about getting the rare RIG shot which unvaccinatef people need to get at any cost.
data.author: Andrea Collisson

data.text: yourreply post is confusing. First you say the vaccination isnt effective, then you say you havent seen any breakthrough infections. What is your actual explanation for your first statement be ause your se ond dorsnt support your first. On the other hand you confusingly mention a rabies case in someone who had preecposure shots. But you do know, i hope, that you should get a furthercoupke of shots if you do get bitten, and also that there is a limited period of protection for the first pre- exposure shots- which is about two years.
data.author: Andrea Collisson

data.text:
Typically if there's an exposure event, then you probably should get additional treatment. Also, there's evidence that washing the would with soap (or iodine) would also reduce the risk of rabies substantially. Typically those with a prior set of vaccination could get a booster shot, rather than a full set of immunoglobulin. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1199013/
Avoiding rabies: Get vaccinated before travel, avoid animals, and get help urgently if bitten
ncbi.nlm.nih.gov
data.author: Stephen Cieply

data.text: Best advice is to not stop and pet stray animals. I spoke to a travel clinic about this and they told me that almost all cases of people getting bitten is because people can't resist talking to and playing with stray dogs.

data.text: Rabies vaccine needs to be stored @ 2-4 deg C, doesn't it? I have to carry around a thermos with my 2nd shot of the vaccine, and looking for ice around rural Tibet(harder than it sounds), after getting bit by a Tibetan mastiff that I didn't try to pet. üòÖ
data.author: Lawrence Liang

data.text: why didnt you stay in the place where you can get the shot from theclinic? You are taking a big risk by continuing on your tour.
data.author: Andrea Collisson

data.text: You can get vaccinated before travel if you have indications for it. People who might have exposure to rabies such as lab workers, animal control, etc., get it.
data.author: Stephen Cieply

data.text: I bought and administered my vaccines in the towns that I stopped. I believe there is several weeks wait between doses
data.author: Jerry Kopack

data.text: Great post for the bike packing community. Im a doctor based in Dubai, from where people launch interesting trips in africa and asia all the time. I recommend you get your rabies vaccine well ahead of the trip. Otherwise you will get bit / scratched by a cat / dog / monkey / rodent / bat somewhere along your trip more likely in a less urban area and then you will have to worry / stress / anguish about what to do and seek healthcare amongst under resourced villages. You will be told conflicting things about the best next steps. You will eventually have to alter plans and head to the capital city where the rabies vaccine and reliable advice are more available. Once they see that beautiful western / first world passport they have you over the barrel and the cost of rabies treatment suddenly becomes incomprehensibly expensive. Best to get full course of rabies vaccination in home country before departing.
data.author: Mark Janowski

data.text: on my global travels, I was always amazed how many broke people are out travelling. If you can‚Äôt even afford a vaccine, stay home, get a job, work until you can afford basics. I saw a Spanish girl crash a scooter, rip her leg open, and then couldn‚Äôt pay for any treatment in south east Asia. She kept swimming in seawater because someone told her it was great for wounds. I kept seeing her sitting around bar for a week or more but the leg kept changing colour. Eventually it had a bad smell too. I heard she was waiting for someone to send her money as I was heading to next destination. All her ‚Äúfriends‚Äù abandoned her. Moral of story: Don‚Äôt travel without insurance or lots of savings
data.author: –î—Ä–∞–≥–ø—É—Ç–∏–Ω –®–∞—ô–∏–≤—ü–∏—ò–∞

data.text: I hate to agree, but a good comprehensive insurance is an absolute priority. I have never needed to use mine, but my Girlfriend did at the time. It came as complete (not exactly life saver) but it felt good her having her own room in a hospital surrounded by Western Doctors...
data.author: David Eldred

data.text: i comoletely agree with advantages of having rabies vaccines. If you are in amy doubt you can google the prevalence of rabies in any of the countries you are travelling through and then take your chances if you get bitten. But for peace of mind, get the shots before you go. Once you get bitten by something when someone mentions the potential of rabies you will have no peace unril you are able to fly back to europe for the only shot that can give you protection prior to the ordinary vaccines developing their efficacy. That means there is a window between being bitten and the efficacy of the other vaccines and in that window you could develop rabies. If you develop rabies you will die!
data.author: Andrea Collisson

data.text: is correct.. rabies is 100% fatal if you are not previously vaccinated or get a dose of the immune globulin within. A week of being bitten/scratched. It is actually a confusong subject to describe, but trust me as a doctor anyone planning a long trip through Africa/ India/Asia. Get the full course of rabies vaccinations and have them completed at least 3 months before you depart on your trip. If you do this you will be bulletproof and wont have to interrupt your trip in the event of being bitten / scratched by an unexpected animal encounter
data.author: Mark Janowski

data.text: Good advice Mark! I ended up doing the full 3 course in Zambia.
data.author: Jerry Kopack

data.text:
It's not 100%. There has actually been one case of someone who has survived rabies without a vaccination, but I wouldn't take those odds. https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/jeanna-giese-rabies-survivor/
Medical Mystery: Only One Person Has Survived Rabies without Vaccine--But How?
scientificamerican.com

data.text: It's rather rare in the US, because of mandatory dog vaccination and even wildlife vaccination programs. There are only 1-3 human cases per year. However, wildlife can indeed have it, for instance there was a rabid fox that roamed around the US capitol and bit a number of people.
data.author: Stephen Cieply
